Problem:
Consider the complex function \( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \) applied to a linear system characterized by \( \dot{x} = Dx \), where \( D \) is a constant matrix and \( \omega \) is a real number. The system's evolution is influenced by the Fourier transform, denoted as \( \mathcal{F}\{x(t)\} \), which transforms \( x(t) \) into the frequency domain.

If \( z(t) \) is applied to the initial state vector \( x_0 \) at t = 0, and then \( x(t) \) evolves under \( \dot{x} = Dx \) with \( z(t) \) being the only transformation applied, will the Fourier transform \( \mathcal{F}\{x(T)\} \) at time T represent the same frequency components as the untransformed system evolved to time T?
Explanation: Applying \( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \) modifies the frequency content of \( x(t) \), adding a component at the frequency \( \omega \). Even though the system evolves according to \( \dot{x} = Dx \), the initial multiplication by \( z(t) \) introduces a new frequency component, which will be evident in \( \mathcal{F}\{x(T)\} \), differing from that of the original system's natural frequencies determined by \( D \).
